title: GCF Calculator – Greatest Common Factor of 2 or More Numbers

formulas.title: Formula (extracted LaTeX)
formulas.latex: \gcd(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_k) = \max\{ d \in \mathbb{N} \,:\, d \mid a_i \text{ for all } i \}.
formulas.raw: \gcd(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_k) = \max\{ d \in \mathbb{N} \,:\, d \mid a_i \text{ for all } i \}.

formulas.title: Formula (extracted LaTeX)
formulas.latex: a = p_1^{\alpha_1} p_2^{\alpha_2} \cdots p_m^{\alpha_m}, \quad b = p_1^{\beta_1} p_2^{\beta_2} \cdots p_m^{\beta_m}
formulas.raw: a = p_1^{\alpha_1} p_2^{\alpha_2} \cdots p_m^{\alpha_m}, \quad b = p_1^{\beta_1} p_2^{\beta_2} \cdots p_m^{\beta_m}

formulas.title: Formula (extracted text)
formulas.raw: \[ \gcd(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_k) = \max\{ d \in \mathbb{N} \,:\, d \mid a_i \text{ for all } i \}. \]

formulas.title: Formula (extracted text)
formulas.raw: Compute the remainder: \(a = q_1 b + r_1\), with \(0 \le r_1 < b\). If \(r_1 = 0\), then \(\gcd(a, b) = b\). Otherwise, replace \((a, b)\) by \((b, r_1)\) and repeat until the remainder is 0. The last non-zero remainder is the GCF. This works because \(\gcd(a, b) = \gcd(b, r_1) = \gcd(r_1, r_2) = \dots\).

formulas.title: Formula (extracted text)
formulas.raw: If \[ a = p_1^{\alpha_1} p_2^{\alpha_2} \cdots p_m^{\alpha_m}, \quad b = p_1^{\beta_1} p_2^{\beta_2} \cdots p_m^{\beta_m} \] where \(p_i\) are the primes appearing in at least one factorization, then \[ \gcd(a, b) = p_1^{\min(\alpha_1, \beta_1)} p_2^{\min(\alpha_2, \beta_2)} \cdots p_m^{\min(\alpha_m, \beta_m)}. \]

changes: Initial audit spec draft generated from HTML extraction (review required).
